stories.label: How do we know when writing emerged in China?
stories.content: There is no way to tell exactly when or how writing emerged in China because the earliest writing--possibly inscribed on bamboo or fabric--have long since disappeared. But we do have evidence of a fully functioning writing system by the second half of the Shang Dynasty (c. 1600–1046 BC), thanks to the durability of the material it was written on:  bone. These pieces were used in rituals to try to foretell the future, so they are known as “oracle bones.”

stories.label: How did ancient kings use animal bones to talk to the dead?
stories.content: Shang kings used oracle bones like these to consult their ancestors and to ask them to serve as intemediaries to the high god, Di, and to the powers of rivers, mountains, rain, and thunder. A Shang king’s king’s authority depended in part on his ability to speak to his ancestors on behalf of the community and foretell the best course of action.

The inscription reads, “…divine…will not bin…

stories.label: What did the king talk to his dead ancestors about?
stories.content: During a divination, a Shang king or his diviner asked the king’s ancestors to fortell the outcome of hunts, the weather, travelling, births, the causes of disease, or the likelihood of war or disaster. The oracle bones recorded a statement, known as the “charge” and the response—a confirmation or denial—that the diviner (sometimes the king himself) interpreted. These dialogues created the first historical records in China.
stories.caption: This illustration shows an oracle bone divination:  the “preface” recording date and diviner; positive and negative versions of a statement or “charge”; the forecast or “prognostication”; and the outcome, or “verification.”
